Enhanced bifunctional oxygen electrochemical catalytic performance using La-doped CoFe2O4 spinel supported by 3D-G for Zn-air batteries Yinggang Sun Tingwei Zhang Peng Sun Jigang Wang Wenjie Duan Yanqiong Zhuang Likai Wang Zhongfang Li ⁎ School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong University of Technology, Zibo 255049, Shandong, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Shandong University of Technology Zibo Shandong 255049 China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong University of Technology, Zibo 255049, Shandong, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract La-doped CoFe2O4 produces the Jahn-Teller effect, which exposes more active sites and reduces the adsorption barrier of ORR and OER intermediates. La transfers Co electrons to the octahedral Fe site as an “electron pump” to improve the electrocatalytic performance. This work presents a viable strategy for utilizing REM-doped spinels to enhance oxygen catalyst and ZABs performance. The preparation of bifunctional catalysts for oxygen reduction (ORR) and oxygen evolution (OER) is crucial for Zn-air batteries. Here, we report a La doped CoFe2O4 spinel catalyst supported on three-dimensional graphene (3D-G), where La can facilitate electron transfer from Co to Fe, leading to increased electron cloud density in Fe and improved catalytic performance. The redshift of the G peak in the Raman spectra indicates the interaction between the π bond of 3D-G and d orbitals in La0.2CoFe1.8O4. La0.2CoFe1.8/3D-G exhibits superior ORR performance (E 1/2 = 0.86 V vs. RHE) and OER performance (Ej =10 = 1.55 V vs. RHE) to CoFe2O4/3D-G (E 1/2 = 0.831 V vs. RHE, Ej =10 = 1.603 V vs. RHE). Furthermore, it demonstrates excellent bifunctional oxygen catalytic performance while maintaining high power density and stability in liquid zinc-air batteries (ZABs) and flexible ZABs (F-ZABs). This work presents a viable strategy for utilizing rare earth element doped spinels to enhance oxygen catalyst and ZABs performance. Keywords Zn-air batteries Electrocatalysts La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G Electron pump Bifunctional oxygen catalytic performance 1 Introduction With the deterioration of energy structure and environmental pollution, the development of green energy conversion and storage technologies such as metal-air batteries has emerged as a promising research field. Rechargeable zinc-air batteries (r-ZABs) are distinguished by their high energy density [1,2], low cost [3,4], and environmental friendliness [5,6], and are poised to emerge as a highly promising electrochemical power supply device in the future. Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [7–9] and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are the key electrochemical reactions in the charge and discharge process of chemical energy conversion into electrical energy in ZABs. However, the slow dynamics and complex reaction pathways of cathodes of ZABs limit their energy efficiency [10,11], stability [12,13], and rechargeable efficiency [14], far from reaching practical commercial applications. The development of highly efficient bifunctional oxygen catalysts is necessary to promote reaction kinetics and increase ORR and OER performance. Pt/C and RuO2 catalysts are widely regarded as benchmarks for ORR and OER, respectively. However, these precious metal catalysts are limited due to their high cost [15], scarcity [16], and poor stability [17]. To solve these problems, efforts have been made to explore low-cost and abundant catalysts such as metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N-C) [12,18–20], transition metal oxides (TMOs) [15,21–24], metal nitrides, heteroatom (N, P, and S) doped carbon [25,26], and multi-alloy catalysts [9,27]. TMOs have become the focus of research on cathode catalysts of ORR, as abundant reserves, low price, simple preparation, and environmental friendliness [28,29]. At present, TMOs can be divided into mono-metal oxides [30,31], perovskite oxides [29,32,33], and spinel oxides [22,34]. Metal oxides with spinel structures have attracted much attention because of their high catalytic performance and good stability. The doping of M3+ (M3+ = Fe, Mn, and Ni) into octahedral sites can change the electronic structure of spinel and affect the catalytic performance [4,28,30]. Such as, Co3+ doped NiMn2O4 can increase the electron cloud density of octahedral active sites, and the catalytic performance of the NiCoMnO4 can thus be enhanced [12,35,36]. W-doped NiCo2O4 spinel was synthesized by high-valence oxyanion exchange strategy [37]. The CuMn0.5Co2O4 catalyst possessed the enhanced Co2+/Co3+ ratio and high concentration of oxygen vacancies, which facilitated enhancing OER performance [18,38]. La in LaMnCo2O4 affirmed the roles as dopants in enhancing oxide conductivity and increasing surface defect or oxygen vacancies for better OER activity according to the design concept [39]. Therefore, the electronic structure of metal ions can be changed by doping and substitution of metal ions in spinel, which can improve the catalytic performance of spinel [28,40]. Rare earth materials (REM), known as “industrial monosodium glutamate”, have unique physical and chemical properties [41]. The large atomic radius of REM could adjust the structure of spinel oxides to achieve the Jahn-Teller effect on the spinel structure to expose more active sites [6,7,16]. In perovskite materials, there are many reports on the use of REM to regulate the internal electronic structure. La can accommodate and transport electrons, because of its particular 4f orbital, and therefore can be used as an “electron pump” to adjust the electronic balance. The coupling of REM with 3d transition metal can be a feasible method to improve the oxygen catalytic performance of the catalyst. La does not directly participate in the electrocatalytic process, but it changes the electron cloud density of Co octahedral sites and improves the OER catalytic performance of LaMnCo2O4 [39]. According to previous reports, CoFe2O4 has good bifunctional oxygen catalytic performance. Could the method of REM atom doping improve the catalytic performance of CoFe2O4? If La3+ replaces part of Fe3+ to change the spinel structure of CoFe2O4, would it change the electronic structure? However, the use of REM doping to CoFe2O4 and its application in oxygen catalysis have not been reported. It is noted that the catalyst performance of spinel CoFe2O4 has been limited by low conductivity and agglomeration during the ORR. To overcome these problems, supporting the metal oxides on carbon-based materials is an effective approach, such as modified one-dimensional carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [42,43], two-dimensional (2D) graphene (2D-G) [36], and three-dimensional (3D) graphene (3D-G) [44]. In particular, the recently reported 3D-G shows a huge specific surface area, high conductivity, and enormous defects [2], which has been considered as one of the best supports. Meanwhile, the synergistic effect between graphene and spinel is beneficial to electrocatalytic performance for ORR [45]. With a large conjugate system, 3D-G has big π bonds that can interact with the d orbitals of transition metals to improve the electron transfer efficiency, enhancing the catalytic performance and stability of the catalyst [46,47]. Herein, we have explored a hydrothermal method to prepare La0.2CoFe1.8O4, which is in situ grown on 3D-G. To prove that La doping changes the crystal structure of CoFe2O4, the La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G is characterized by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) and X-ray diffraction (XRD). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is used to determine the transformation of the electron binding energy of the three elements Co, La, and Fe. To further discuss the effect of La doping on CoFe2O4 structure, density functional theory (DFT) studies are introduced to compare the electron cloud density at the Fe octahedral site after La doping, and the adsorption energy for the intermediate on the Fe site is calculated. The bifunctional performance of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G is tested in terms of ORR and OER. Assembly of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G based liquid ZABs and flexible solid-state ZABs is carried out for testing peak power density and stability. The potential application of this technique in flexible electronic products is shown by bending at different angles. This work provides a novel strategy to develop advanced bifunctional electrocatalysts for high-efficiency metal-air batteries under alkaline conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (1.8 mmol), La(NO3)3 (0.2 mmol), and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (1.0 mmol) were dissolved in dilute acetic acid solution (15 mL), respectively. 3D-G (0.72 g) was dispersed into 10 mL ethanol to form a homogeneous mixture and then poured into the above solution. The NH3·H2O (5 mL) was added into the mixed solution and reacted for 20 min. The precursor was added into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave and kept at 160 °C for 6 h. The reaction mixture was centrifugally washed with deionized water four times. The gained products were dried at 70 °C for 12 h in an oven and activated under a N2 atmosphere for 2 h at 300, 400, and 500 °C, respectively. The samples were named as La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G-300, La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G, La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G-500. Meanwhile, a series of samples were prepared by changing the ratio of La to Fe, which were named as La0.1CoFe1.9O4/3D-G, La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G, and La0.3CoFe1.7O4/3D-G. The samples of CoFe2O4/3D-G were prepared using the same method without adding La(NO3)3. 2.2 Theoretical calculations The first-principles DFT calculations were investigated within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) through the Vienna abinitio simulation package (VASP) [48]. We built molecular models featuring periodicity in both the x and y directions, and the vacuum layer's depth exceeded 10 Å to avoid any self-interactions. The calculations were conducted by the GGA using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) formulation. We also took advantage of the projector augmented wave (PAW) potential to describe the interactions, and the Kohn-Sham one-electron valence states were expanded based on plane waves with a cutoff energy of 470 eV. The Hellmann-Feynman forces convergence criterion was established at less than 0.05 eV Å−1, and a k-point grid of 2 × 2 × 1 was employed for optimizing all molecular models. Additionally, we conducted the electrostatic potential and electron localization function (ELF) during single-point energy calculations. The electronic energy is considered to be self-coincidental when the energy gap is less than 10−5 eV. The k-point parameter and cutoff energy are consistent with the process of structure optimization [49]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and structural characterization La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G was prepared by the in-situ growth in multi-channel 3D-G (Scheme 1 ). The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) showed that La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G had a multi-level porous structure (Fig. S1). La0.2CoFe1.8O4 spinels were uniformly distributed on the surface defects of 3D-G layer. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) could observe that Co, Fe, La, and O elements were well distributed throughout the region. TEM image of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G and 3D-G (Fig. 1 a and Fig. S2) showed an obvious foamlike porous structure. HR-TEM of La0.2CoFe1.8O4 (Fig. 1b) showed the lattice spacing of 0.3 and 0.26 nm, corresponding to the (311) and (220) facet of CoFe2O4. In Fig. 1(c and d), the inverse Fast Fourier transform (FFT) image was generated from selected diffraction spot arrays in Fig. 1(b), showing clear lattices. It indicated the incorporation of La with a larger atomic radius and increased crystal spacing of the (220) plane (0.29 to 0.30 nm) in Fig. 1(d). The crystal spacing of (311) plane had a similar increase from 0.25 to 0.26 nm in Fig. 1(c). As a REM with a large radius, La replacing part of Fe was doped into the octahedral structure of CoFe2O4 spinel, resulting in lattice distortion. The distortion of two crystal planes was represented at different conditions, which verified that La had been inserted into the CoFe2O4 spinel. Moreover, the Selected area electron diffraction (SAED) with different diffraction spots can be observed in Fig. 1(e), further confirming the crystal structure. The bright spots with different brightness and darkness can be observed in High angle annular dark field (HAADF) (Fig. 1f), testifying to the formation of La0.2CoFe1.8O4, which was about 15 nm in size. As depicted in Fig. 1(g), the different elements (Co, Fe, La, and O) were uniformly dispersed on the surface of spinel crystals, which were anchored to the surface of 3D-G (Fig. 1h–k). XRD was employed for the analysis of phase and lattice parameters of the prepared catalysts. Fig. 2 (a) illustrated the characteristic XRD pattern of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G, CoFe2O4/3D-G, and 3D-G. The well-defined peaks at 2θ = ∼18.4°, ∼29.2°, ∼34.5°, ∼35.5°, ∼42.2°, ∼53.5°, ∼56.0°, and 62.8° can be attributed to the spinel phase of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G based on Bragg's law, whereas for CoFe2O4/3D-G, the distinct peaks at ∼18.4°, ∼29.3°, ∼35.5°, 37.0°, ∼43.0°, ∼53.4°, ∼56.9°, and ∼62.5° correspond to the phase of CoFe2O4 (JCPDS No.22-1086). The two main peaks at ∼25° and ∼43° were attributed to graphene sheets in 3D-G. XRD patterns manifested that the insertion of different proportions of La into CoFe2O4 resulted in a shift in the peak position. Some characteristic peaks of La2O3 appeared in La0.3CoFe1.7O4/3D-G, which was unfavorable to the oxygen catalyzed reaction (Fig. S3). Among the materials obtained at different activation temperatures (Fig. S4), La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G-500 had the most obvious and sharp characteristic peaks, which proved that La0.2CoFe1.8O4 had the most volume at 500 °C, nano-spinel agglomeration explaining it. The peak position of (311) and (220) in La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G exhibited a shift towards lower angles compared with that of CoFe2O4/3D-G in Fig. 2(b) by 1° and 0.1° respectively. Accordingly, the (311) and (220) plane spacings of La0.2CoFe1.8O4 were calculated to be 0.26 and 0.30 nm, which was consistent with the result from HR-TEM. The blue shift of the (311) and (220) planes indicated that La was incorporated into La0.2CoFe1.8O4 to form a single-phase structure. It demonstrated that La alters crystal plane spacing due to its significant change of the atomic size. High-index crystal faces typically serve as catalytically active centers for spinel. Therefore, La improved catalytic performance by modifying exposed crystal face structures. No peak corresponding to La2O3 or other phases were detected, suggesting four elements stabilized within a single-phase lattice structure. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G and 3D-G were typical IV isotherms with obvious hysteresis loops (Fig. 2c), which showed that two materials had typical mesoporous. The corresponding specific surface area of the two materials was 954.6 and 1943.1 m2 g−1, respectively. Compared with pure 3D-G, La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G showed a lower specific surface area after it was composited with 3D-G, which was caused by spinel La0.2CoFe1.8O4 adhered to the defects of the 3D-G surface. The pore size distribution curve (simulated by the DFT model) of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G and 3D-G were shown in Fig. 2(d). The La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G had abundant pore structure. The increase of micropores was produced due to the fact that small-size La0.2CoFe1.8O4 occupied mesopores of 3D-G. Similarly, there was one mesoporous peak corresponding to the hysteresis loop in the isotherm of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G and 3D-G, with a broad peak at 20 nm, which was produced by a 20 nm MgO template. Coal tar pitch (CTP) was decomposed during pyrolysis to produce abundant porous structure. KOH corroded the carbon material to produce enormous micropores and defective structures. La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G with unique interconnected hierarchical 3D graphene structure possessed high surface area and exposed more defects, which was beneficial to enhancing mass transfer and facilitating diffusion kinetics for improvement of the electrocatalytic performance for ORR. The prospect of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G as an efficient electrocatalyst was suggested. The Raman spectra (Fig. 2e and f) of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G, CoFe2O4/3D-G, and 3D-G had main bands at 1590 cm−1 (G band) and 1350 cm−1 (D band), which arose from the sp 2-hybridized graphitic carbon atoms and defective graphitic structures, respectively. Moreover, the peak of the G band in La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G presented a redshift (approximately 8 cm−1) compared with that in 3D-G, and CoFe2O4 had a smaller shift (approximately 6 cm−1) than La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G (Fig. 2f). The low energy gap was created, which proved the interaction between the d-orbit of spinel and π bond of 3D-G. It indicated that La caused the CoFe2O4 to expose more sites of d-orbit. The calculated I D/I G ratios of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G, CoFe2O4/3D-G, and 3D-G were 1.11, 1.09, and 1.01, respectively. The result indicated that La0.2CoFe1.8O4 anchored on the 3D-G increased the structural defects and thus more active sites were exposed. The distinct increased in the I D/I G ratio for La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G was ascribed to the increase in the number of defects, which indicated the spinel La0.2CoFe1.8O4 anchored on 3D-G. An obvious 2D peak was observed at 2800 cm−1. The calculated I G/I 2D ratios of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G, CoFe2O4/3D-G, and 3D-G were 3.85, 3.79, and 3.11, respectively, which indicated that the La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G was multilayer graphene with 3–7 layers. The value of I G /I 2D (La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G) was higher than that of 3D-G, which indicated that the thickness of the pore walls of 3D-G was increased after the La0.2CoFe1.8O4 was anchored on the surface of 3D-G. The surface chemical states of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G were characterized by XPS. Fig. S5 displayed the full peaks of the character peaks of La, Co, Fe, O, and C in La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G. The atomic ratio was 2.3: 4.5: 0.5: 10.1: 82.6 (Co: Fe: La: O: C in La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G), which was in good agreement with La0.2CoFe1.8O4 (Table S1). The result for CoFe2O4 also fits the desired structure. In the C spectra (Figs. S6a and S7a), there appeared deconvolution which was attributed to four peaks: C–C (∼284.8 eV), C=C (∼284.1 eV), C=O (∼288.9 eV), and C–O (∼285.54 eV), respectively. In Fig. S6(b), the O 1s spectra of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G had three characteristic peaks at ∼530.8, ∼531.9, and ∼533.3 eV, which were associated with the M–O–M, O=C–O, and O=C, respectively. The same structure appeared in CoFe2O4/3D-G (Fig. S7). Fig. 2(g) shows two main peaks (Co 2p 3/2, ∼780.3 eV and Co 2p 1/2, ∼796.3 eV) of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G, which proved the presence of Co2+ cations in La0.2CoFe1.8O4. It was worth noting that the Co 2p peak of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G had lower binding energy than that of CoFe2O4/3D-G (Co 2p 3/2, ∼780.8 eV and Co 2p 1/2, ∼796.9 eV). The peak of Co 2p 3/2 had the 0.5 eV blue shifts to low binding energy in La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G compared with CoFe2O4/3D-G. The same phenomenon had occurred in Fe 2p, while the Fe 2p peaks of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G had higher binding energy (Fe 2p 3/2, ∼711.9 eV and Fe 2p 1/2, ∼723.9 eV) than CoFe2O4/3D-G (Fe 2p 3/2, ∼710.8 eV and Fe 2p 1/2, ∼724.3 eV). The peak of Fe 2p 3/2 had 1.2 eV redshifts to high binding energy in La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G compared with CoFe2O4/3D-G (Fig. 2h). As shown in Fig. 2(i), the La 3d spectra showed two peaks located at ∼840.1 and ∼852.5 eV, corresponding to La 3d 5/2 and La 3d 1/2, respectively. In comparison, the doping of La changed the binding energy of Fe, making the two main peaks move toward the direction of high binding energy (Fig. 2h). It indicated that La played a role as an “electron pump”, which can adjust the electronic structure of spinel. 3.2 Performance evaluation of oxygen reduction reaction The catalytic ORR performances of catalysts were tested in an O2-saturated 0.1 mol L−1 KOH solution. As shown in Fig. S8(a and c), different proportions of La x CoFe2− x O4/3D-G were prepared, and La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G had the best performance. The catalytic ORR performances of the catalysts activated at temperatures of 300, 400, and 500 °C were further studied by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) (Fig. S8b and d). The catalyst activated at 400 °C had the best catalytic performance (Figs. S3 and S4). The XRD (Fig. S4) showed that a small amount of La was not enough to affect the structure of spinel to expose the active site, and too much La incorporation will produce La2O3 to hinder the catalytic reaction. The high-index crystal face was usually the crystal face in which spinel participates in the reaction. La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G-300 °C is not enough for spinel growth to expose the high-index crystal surface (311), and 500 °C will cause agglomeration of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G, which was not conducive to exposing the active site (Fig. S9). The cyclic voltammetry (CV) showed that the La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G, CoFe2O4/3D-G, 3D-G, and commercial Pt/C had redox peaks in the O2-saturated solution and no redox reaction in the N2-saturated 0.1 mol L−1 KOH (Fig. 3 a). Fig. 3(b) showed the LSV of samples at the rotating speed of 1600 r min−1. The onset potential E onset and half-wave potential (E 1/2) of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G were 0.92 and 0.86 V (vs. RHE), respectively. These key values were slightly higher than Pt/C (E onset = 0.92 V and E 1/2 = 0.85 V), and much higher than CoFe2O4/3D-G (E onset = 0.91 V and E 1/2 = 0.831 V) and 3D-G (E onset = 0.78 V and E 1/2 = 0.71 V). Fig. 3(c) was the Tafel plots of different catalysts, and La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G had the smallest value (65 mV dec−1) in these catalysts. It indicated that the La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G has the best catalytic kinetic efficiency. Linear fitting of LSV (Fig. 3d and Fig. S10) at different rates was performed to obtain a K-L diagram (Fig. S11) and calculate the electron transfer number (n) of the catalyzed ORR. The number of electron transfers was 3.99, 3.90, and 3.85 for La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G, CoFe2O4/3D-G, and 3D-G at 0.7 V vs. RHE, respectively (Fig. 3e). Meanwhile, Fig. 3(f) showed the average n of 3.98 for the La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G calculated from the rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) (CoFe2O4/3D-G, n = 3.90), suggesting that La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G was efficient 4e− ORR procedure and thus demonstrating the catalyst had high selectivity in efficiency. In addition, electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) was an important indicator to evaluate the catalyst performance. The CV curves (Fig. S12) with different scan rates (20, 40, 60, 80, 100, and 120 mV s−1) from 0.90 to 1.1 V vs. RHE were measured to calculate the ECSA. ECSA (Fig. 3g) of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G was 11 mF cm−2 more than CoFe2O4/3D-G (3.14 mF cm−2), demonstrating that La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G owns large electrochemical surface areas and more catalytic active sites. The i-t chronoamperometric curves showed that the current density of the La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G decreased 5%, and CoFe2O4/3D-G and Pt/C decreased 11.2% and 32.8% at 0.5 V after testing for 40,000 s, respectively (Fig. 3h), which proved that La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G had the best stability. As expected, the E 1/2 of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G shifted only 11 mV in the accelerated durability test (ADT) (Fig. 3i), which was smaller than that of 20 wt% Pt/C (20 mV) and CoFe2O4/3D-G (15 mV) as shown in Fig. S13. Therefore, the above results provide the direct evidence that La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G exhibited remarkable catalytic performance, stability, and remarkable selectivity for ORR. Compared with the previous reports (Table S2), La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G had good bifunction oxygen performance. After the doping of La to spinel, a synergistic effect was achieved. La affected the structure of spinel to produce the Jahn-Teller effect, exposed more active sites, and enhanced the catalytic performance of spinel. 3.3 Performance evaluation of oxygen evolution reaction The OER performances of the catalyst were tested in 1 mol L−1 KOH solution. The LSV curves of different samples at 1600 r min−1 were displayed in Fig. 4 (a). The potential/overpotential at the current density 10 mA cm−2 of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G, CoFe2O4/3D-G, 3D-G, and RuO2 catalyst was 1.55 V vs. RHE/320 mV, 1.603 V vs. RHE/373 mV, 1.77 V vs. RHE/540 mV, and 1.56 V vs. RHE/330 mV, respectively. The La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G had the smallest overpotential among the catalysts, which was attributed to the doping of La (Fig. S14). Fig. 4(b) displays the Tafel slope of the samples. The Tafel slope of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G was 140 mV dec−1, which was lower than that of RuO2 (160 mV dec−1), CoFe2O4/3D-G (149 mV dec−1), and 3D-G (268 mV dec−1). La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G had the best reaction kinetics to accelerate the catalytic OER process. The durability of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G, CoFe2O4/3D-G, and RuO2 was studied by ADT (Fig. 4c). After 5000 cycles of CV test, the overpotential of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G increased by 10 mV, which was lower than RuO2 (30 mV) and CoFe2O4/3D-G (13 mV) (Fig. 4d). The i-t chronoamperometry (Fig. 4e) showed the OER chronoamperometric responses at 1.6 V vs. RHE. The current density of the La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G decreased by 8% after 40,000 s (CoFe2O4/3D-G 12% and RuO2 25%). The result showed that the La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G had better stability than CoFe2O4/3D-G and RuO2. The above data suggested that La doping has an optimization effect on the internal structure of spinel. At the same time, the catalyst had a certain bifunctional effect on ORR and OER. The overall oxygen electrode performance (ΔE = E j=10 − E 1/2) is the standard to evaluate the bifunctional performance. The ΔE of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G, CoFe2O4/3D-G, 3D-G, Pt/C, and RuO2 were 0.69, 0.772, 0.99, 0.85, and 0.86 V, respectively. The above result showed that La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G had good bifunctional oxygen catalytic properties (Fig. 4f), which was the best bifunctional oxygen catalyst. The La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G exhibited superior performance compared to the findings in the previous report (Table S2). 3.4 DFT calculations To further study the CoFe2O4 and La0.2CoFe1.8O4 theoretically, the spinel catalysts were simulated with DFT as shown in Fig. 5 . Fe, as the octahedral site of spinel, was the active center of spinel catalyst. The models of CoFe2O4 and La0.2CoFe1.8O4 (Fe site) with their adsorption intermediates (*OOH, *O, and *OH) had been geometrically structured as shown in Fig. 5(a and b). The four-electron ORR pathways were investigated on CoFe2O4 and La0.2CoFe1.8O4 models. As shown in Fig. 5(c), the change in Gibbs free energy (ΔG) was studied at two distinct electrode potentials: U = 1.23 V and U = 0 V. The rate determining step was the first step of ORR, which demonstrated a high energy barrier that limits the ORR; the energy barriers were decreased with the introduction of La for CoFe2O4. The energy barriers of the rate-determining step were similar for the two samples. La0.2CoFe1.8O4 showed slightly better performance than CoFe2O4. The other reaction steps were downhill, implying that the electron-transfer steps were generally exothermic. Meanwhile, the *OOH → *O step of La0.2CoFe1.8O4 had a significantly lower energy barrier compared to CoFe2O4, suggesting that the presence of the doping of La also improved the ORR catalytic performance. Hence the introduction of La for CoFe2O4 played a crucial role in enhancing the overall performance. The density of state (DOS) and band structure of CoFe2O4 and La0.2CoFe1.8O4 were deeply calculated using the CASTEP module in Material Studios (Fig. 5d). La0.2CoFe1.8O4 had a lower d-band center compared to CoFe2O4. According to the d-band center theory, the lower d-band center will lead to the weakening of the binding effect between the catalyst and the intermediate, which is conducive to the desorption process and accelerating the oxygen catalytic process. In addition, the energy band structure of La0.2CoFe1.8O4, as shown in Fig. 5(e and f) and Fig. S15(a and b), clearly indicated the absence of forbidden band. The above results indicated that La0.2CoFe1.8O4 exhibited conductive properties, and the doping of La cannot change the conduction property. Fig. 5(g) showed the electrostatic potential (ESP) of CoFe2O4 and La0.2CoFe1.8O4, which can reflect the electron cloud structure and density. The electron density analysis of La0.2CoFe1.8O4 revealed a pronounced concentration of negative and positive charge distribution, highlighting the evident electronic properties and synergistic effects among La, Fe, and Co atoms. After La doping, the blue area in the center of Co became lighter, and the center of Fe atoms changed from green to red, which made the electron cloud around Co decreased and the electron cloud density of Fe increase due to La doping. La transferred electrons around Co to Fe to increase the density of the electron cloud at Fe. This result was consistent with the shift of the Co and Fe high-resolution XPS spectra. In summary, there were two reasons for the best catalytic performance of La0.2CoFe1.8O4. Firstly, the introduction of La results in lattice distortion and the Jahn-Teller effect, which exposed more octahedral catalytic active sites and reduced the adsorption energy barrier of reaction intermediates. Secondly, the doped of La promoted the electron migration from Co to Fe, increased the density of the Fe electron cloud, and improved the oxygen catalytic performance. 3.5 Liquid Zn-air batteries evaluation La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G was coated on the cathode of the Zn-air batteries (ZABs) and tested in an alkaline electrolyte (Fig. 6 a). The ZABs with La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G demonstrated a peak power density of 341.9 mW cm−2 as displayed in Fig. 6(b), much higher than that with CoFe2O4/3D-G (270.7 mW cm−2) and commercial Pt/C and RuO2 catalysts-based ZAB (209.5 mW cm−2). Additionally, the corresponding discharge and charge polarization curves of ZABs were shown in Fig. 6(c), and the La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G displayed a smaller voltage gap (0.77 V) than that with Pt/C + RuO2 (1.1 V) at 50 mA cm−2, implying a higher charge-discharge capacity. As illustrated in Fig. 6(d), La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G had a better open-circuit voltage (1.5 V), which was higher than CoFe2O4/3D-G (1.48 V) and Pt/C + RuO2 (1.385 V). Fig. 6(e) showed the Nyquist plots of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G, CoFe2O4/3D-G, and 20 wt% Pt/C + RuO2. The insert picture in Fig. 6(e) was an equivalent circuit diagram. R Ω represented the impedance of materials and electrolytes in the battery. R ct represented the interface transfer resistance. The radius of the arc was the sum of the internal resistance and the interface transfer resistance. The solution resistance (R Ω) of ZAB with La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G was 4 Ω and the interfacial reaction resistance (R ct) was 15.0 Ω. The R Ω and R ct were smaller than those of ZAB with CoFe2O4/3D-G (R Ω = 8.0 Ω and R ct = 21 Ω) and Pt/C + RuO2 (R Ω = 10 Ω and R ct = 35 Ω). The diffusion process in the La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G Nyquist was closest to 45°, which proved that it had the fastest charge transfer process and mass transfer process. The specific capacity of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G Zn-air battery normalized to the mass loss of Zn plate was about 800.3 mA h gZn −1 at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 6f), which was higher than that of CoFe2O4/3D-G Zn-air battery (742 mA h gZn −1) and Pt/C + RuO2 Zn-air battery. To show the performance of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G Zn-air battery, a red light emitting diode (LED) light of the “SDUT” logo can be powered up by two liquid ZABs with La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G as the air-cathode (Fig. 6g). The discharge and charge curve of the air-cathode was investigated at 10 mA cm−2 in a short period (10 min), as displayed in Fig. 6(h). Obviously, the ZAB with La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G displayed superior cycling stability for more than 140 h, much better than that of CoFe2O4/3D-G (93.5 h) and Pt/C + RuO2 (23.5 h). These results indicated that La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G was an excellent bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst and displayed excellent performance. 3.6 Flexible Zn-air batteries evaluation The schematic diagram (Fig. 7 a) was the composition of F-ZABs using La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G as the air-cathode. The La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G F-ZABs demonstrated a peak power density (Fig. 7b) of 65.5 mW cm−2, and CoFe2O4/3D-G (44.5 mW cm−2) and Pt/C + RuO2 (39.2 mW cm−2), respectively. The voltage gap at 20 mA cm−2 was about 1.14 V (Fig. 7c), implying a stable charge and discharge performance. The F-ZABs had stable open-circuit voltage (Fig. 7d); La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G-based F-ZABs had the best performance (1.503 V), which was higher than Pt/C + RuO2 (1.341 V) and CoFe2O4/3D-G (1.462 V) based F-ZABs. As depicted in Fig. 7(e), the ZAB with La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G displayed superior cycling stability for more than 16 h, much better than that of CoFe1.8O4/3D-G (10.5 h) and Pt/C + RuO2 (8 h). La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G had the smallest gap (0.83 V). A red LED was lit by two all-solid-state ZABs with La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G as the air cathode catalysts in series (Fig. 7f). Notably, the voltage gap (Fig. 7g) presented the negligible change when the flexible battery was bent from 0° to 180° angle, indicating the practicability in portable and wearable electronics fields. These results demonstrated the bright prospects of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G-based all-solid-state ZAB for future flexible electronic devices. 4 Conclusions La0.2CoFe1.8O4 spinel was successfully grown in situ on 3D-G with multiple pore channels by hydrothermal method. The increase in crystal spacing in HR-TEM was an evidence of La doping into the CoFe2O4. According to Bragg's law, the shift of the characteristic plane in XRD corresponds to the increase of the spacing in HR-TEM. The large atomic radius of La adjusted the structure of CoFe2O4 to achieve the Jahn-Teller effect on the spinel structure to expose more active sites. Raman results showed the redshift, proving that there were more d-orbitals in La0.2CoFe1.8O4 to interact strongly with the π bond of 3D-G to improve the activity and stability of the La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G. The results of the XPS and DFT calculation proved that La can transfer the electrons of Co to the Fe active site, increase the electron cloud density of Fe, and improve the catalytic performance. Moreover, the *O → *OH step in the ORR process of La0.2CoFe1.8O4 had a significantly lower energy barrier compared to CoFe2O4. La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G catalyst had the best ORR performance in 0.1 mol L−1 KOH solution (E 1/2 = 0.86 VRHE) compared with the other catalyst. For OER, La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G catalyst showed better catalytic performance at 1 mol L−1 KOH (ƞ = 320 mV) than RuO2 (ƞ = 330 mV). Compared with CoFe2O4/3D-G, the ΔE of La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G decreased by 82 mV. Therefore, La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G is a bifunctional oxygen catalyst with excellent properties. Liquid ZAB with La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G had surprising peak power density (341.5 mW cm−2), durable specific capacity (800.3 mA h gzn −1), and long cycle stability (140 h). The Nyquist spectra proved that the ZABs with La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G had the best process of mass transfer. The catalyst also showed excellent performance in F-ZAB. The doping of REM into the octahedral site of spinel facilitates the modulation of its internal electronic structure, thereby improving both the activity and durability of the La0.2CoFe1.8O4/3D-G. This work presented a viable strategy and mechanistic explanation for enhancing the oxygen catalytic activity by doping rare earth metals. Finally, it provided an efficient bifunctional oxygen catalyst for sustainable ZABs energy storage devices. coredata.dc:description: The preparation of bifunctional catalysts for oxygen reduction (ORR) and oxygen evolution (OER) is crucial for Zn-air batteries. Here, we report a La doped CoFe2O4 spinel catalyst supported on three-dimensional graphene (3D-G), where La can facilitate electron transfer from Co to Fe, leading to increased electron cloud density in Fe and improved catalytic performance. The redshift of the G peak in the Raman spectra indicates the interaction between the π bond of 3D-G and d orbitals in La0.2CoFe1.8O4. La0.2CoFe1.8/3D-G exhibits superior ORR performance (E 1/2 = 0.86 V vs. RHE) and OER performance (Ej =10 = 1.55 V vs. RHE) to CoFe2O4/3D-G (E 1/2 = 0.831 V vs. RHE, Ej =10 = 1.603 V vs. RHE). Furthermore, it demonstrates excellent bifunctional oxygen catalytic performance while maintaining high power density and stability in liquid zinc-air batteries (ZABs) and flexible ZABs (F-ZABs). This work presents a viable strategy for utilizing rare earth element doped spinels to enhance oxygen catalyst and ZABs performance.
